bibl.title: Letter from the Surgeon General's Office to Aristides Agramonte, October 10, 1908

div1.p: Agramonte is notified that his letter has been received and filed for future reference. Agramonte's letter of August 31, 1908, is included, testifying to the sequence of events in the work carried out by the Army Board on Yellow Fever. Included are two notes by Truby. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Notes by Albert E. Truby, [n.d.]
div1.p:
O'Reilly was the S.G. and know
all about Reed's work as well
as what the other members of the
Board had done, He & Kean
then wrote this conciliatory letter.
The S G O was so disgusted with
Carroll's claim that they probably
felt it unwise to air the claims
of Carroll & Agramonte and therefore
trytried to at staveing off action.

Then Torney became S.G and
it was than that Agramonte's letter
was published in the Sen. Doc. with
remarks by Kean who probably felt
that after Carroll's statements the
whole thing would cause a real
mess if published in all details.
Of course this is just a surmise
on my part. I have never seen
the most of the correspondence between
the S.G.O & Agramonte,
aet

Dr Carroll died in 1907. This letter
was written a year later. But
its claims are mild to those
written later. I have made
a few notes on this and
underlined a few important
things.

Lazear's mosquitoes were
all kept at his laboratory at
Col. Bks Hosp. I saw them there
in July and I saw them again
after Lazear's death when Neate
was in charge, but I was responsible
aet
as C.O.

WAR DEPARTMENT,
OFFICE OF THE SURGEON GENERAL,
WASHINGTON
October 10, 1908.
Dr. Aristides Agramonte,
Profesor de Bacteriologia y Patologia Experimental,
Universidad de la Habana, Habana, Cuba.
My dear Doctor Agramonte:
div1.p:
The Surgeon General directs me to say that he has
carefully considered your statements inclosed in your
letter of August 31, 1908, regarding the work carried
out by the Army Board appointed by paragraph 34, Special
Order Bo. 122, series of 1900, and to inform you that
the same has been placed in the files of this office,
so that it will be considered whenever the question of
the discovery that yellow fever was transmitted by
the mosquito is discussed in the future.
div1.closer: Very respectfully, [unclear] Major, Medical Corps, U. S. Army.

div1.head: Letter from Aristides Agramonte to Robert M. O'Reilly, August 31, 1908
div1.opener:
Doc File 71980 War Dept.
Records, of the War Dept, S G O
File No 71980
Dr. Aristides Agramonte
Profesor de Bacteriologia y Patologia Experimental
Facultad de Medicina,
Universidad de la Habana, Cuba.
-----
Vedado, Havana, Cuba, August 31, 1908.
Gen. R. M. O'Reilly, U. S. Army,
Washington, D. C.
My dear General:
div1.p:
In compliance with your request, when I had
the pleasure to see you in Havana, I have the honor to hand you
herein enclosed, a general statement of the manner in which the
work was carried out by the Army Board which demonstrated the
mosquito transmission in yellow fever.

I have never, directly or indirectly, received any material reward for
my share in said researches.

With the hope that it may meet with your approval and best
wishes for yourself, I remain,
div1.closer:
Very sincerely, Aristides Agramonte Aug. 10/10/08
M to H

div1.head: Statement by Aristides Agramonte, August 31, 1908
div1.p:
STATEMENT by Aristides Agramonte, M. D. of Havana, Cuba,
regarding the work carried out by the Army Board, appointed by
paragraph 34, Special Orders No. 122, series of 1900, Headquarters
of the Army. ----------------------------------------------------

This Board was to act under general instructions to be commu-
nicated to Major Reed by the Surgeon General of the Army.

Soon after its appointment, the Board met at Camp Columbia, XX
near the town of Quemados, Cuba.

A mild epidemic of yellow fever was in course of development
in the above mentionned town, so that work was commenced at once.

By tacit consent of all concerned, Maj. Reed was to be the
director of the work which the Board might undertake and which was
devided at the time as follows;
Dr. Carroll, bacteriological work,
Dr. Agramonte, autopsies and gross pathology,
Dr. Lazear, microscopical pathology.

As may be seen, no mosquito investigation was thought of at
that time.

Besides his duties as a member of the Board, Dr. Agramonte had
charge of the Division Laboratory, located in Havana, at the U. S.
Military Hospital No. 1, as per paragraph 3, Special Orders No. 74,
See Agramonte letter to Kean July 3, 1908
============
(2)
from Headquarters Division of Cuba, May 23, 1900.

In June of the same year, an epidemic of yellow fever develop-
ed in the city of Santa Clara and Dr. Agramonte was ordered to in-
vestigate its origin, as per paragraph 3, Special Orders No. 97,
Headquarters Division of Cuba, June 27, 1900.

While examining into the epidemiology of this outburst, the
question of mosquito transmission was fir[unclear]st discussed by Dr. Agra-
monte and he remembers having talked upon the subject with Capt.
Stone, Post Surgeon, at Santa Clara, who was also inclined to be-
lieve in its probability.

Dr. Agramonte returned to his post and the routine work of the
Board was continued, no mosquito work being yet undertaken.

A month after, Dr. Agramonte was ordered to Pinar del Rio “for
the purpose of examining into the exact nature of certain cases of
“pernicious fever reported to have occurred at said post”, as per
paragraph 1, Special Orders No. 112, Headquarters Division of Cuba,
July 17, 1900. He found an epidemic of yellow fever among the troops,
which was not only unrecognized by the Surgeon in charge but actual-
ly denied by him and three other contract surgeons on duty at said
post. In face of this oposition, Dr. Agramonte telegraphed his
opinion to Headquarters within 24 hours after his arrival, assum-
ing all responsibility for his action. An immune surgeon was sent
to look after the sick, Camp was moved to the country and Major
Read came, two days later, to study the possible origin of the infect-
ion. It was there on the ground, that for the first time the proba-
bility of mosquito agency was seriously discussed by members of the
(3)
Board and it was decided to carry out some research in this direct-
ion.

As Dr. Lazear had obtained considerable training in mosquito
work, while in Italy, and none of the other members of the Board had
not true
any, it was agreed that he take up this part of the work in the
beginning. Dr. Carroll continued to investigate the bacteria and
Dr. Agramonte the Pathological anatomy of yellow fever.

Major Reed at this time returned to Washington, for the purpose
of completing the Report upon “Typhoid fever in the Army” in col-
laboration with Drs. Shakespear and Vaughn.

Lazear began to breed, dissect, classify and infect mosquitoes,
in which work, cCarroll and Agramonte took little or no part. Now and
then, Lazear would apply them to whoever allowed it. Most of them mosquitoes
died early in captivity; Lazear, Carroll and several other persons
had been bitten several times by mosquitoes which previously had
fed on yellow fever blood, without result, so that the theory of
mosquito transmission was gradually being discredited, until Carroll
fell sick, on the 30th of August, (1900) entirely innocent of [unclear]
the real nature of his illness.

Suspecting the origin of his infection and its real gravity,
Drs. Lazear and Agramonte decided to test the mosquito which pre-
sumably had caused Carroll's attack by applying it to the first non-
immune individual who might allow it.

Therefor on the afternoon of August 31st, the same mosquito
and three others, were applied to an American soldier who had not
left Columbia Barracks, (which was free from yellow fever,) for 57
(4)
days prior to his inoculation; nor did he go out of a said reservat-
ion before he fell sick with yellow fever, five days afterwards,
thus confirming in our minds the fact that he had been infected by
the mosquito bites.

Dr. Carroll being at this time still suffering from a severe
attack of the disease, Drs. Lazear and Agramonte decided to com-
municate these results to Major Reed who was yet in Washington.

Before Major Reed's arrival in Havana, Dr. Lazear became infect-
ed with yellow fever, his death taking place on the 25th of Sept.

During Carroll's convalescence, the Board decided that the
results of the investigation were so far sufficiently convincing to
justify their presentation, in the shape of a Preliminary Note, be-
fore the coming meeting of the American Public Health Association,
at Indiannapolis, Ind. (Oct. 1900).

Major Reed went North for this purpose, and while Carroll took
a short vacation, to recuperate from his recent attack, Dr. Agra-
monte was charged with breeding and infecting mosquitoes, keeping
them at the Division Laboratory, which was under his care in Havana,
in preparation for the work which the Board intended to carry out
after the Indiannapolis meeting.

When Major Reed returned from the States, moral and material
aid was obtained from Gen. Leonard Wood, commanding the Division,
and we determined to carry out an investigation exclusively based
upon the mosquito theory sustained by Finlay: we knew nothing of
Beauperthuy, then, who in 1853 had defended practically the same
theory.

While the experimental station, afterwards named Camp Lazear,
(5)
in honor to the memory of our deceased colleague, was being establish-
ed, the care of the mosquitoes and their infection by applying them
to yellow fever cases, was in the hands of Dr. Agramonte, at the
Division Laboratory; when the permanent “mosquito building” was
erected at Camp Lazear, (Dec. 1, 1900), these mosquitoes were turn-
ed over to Dr. Carroll for his care. It devolved then to upon Dr. Agra-
monte to select the mosquitoes from those kept by Dr. Carroll and
to apply them to non-immunes, as well as to make all subsequent
direct [unclear] inoculations and to obtain the non-immunes, (Spaniards,)
for the purpose, until the end of the work in Cuba.

Let me add, that the best friendship existed between all the
members of the Board and from the beginning of their work it was
agreed that the honor of the results was to be shared by all alike
as the labor was so evenly shared. Unfortunately this has not been
the case, let us hope through no fault of the Members themselves.
Drs. Reed and Carroll had been connected in laboratory work for
several years and Dr. Agramonte had also worked at the Army Medical
Museum Laboratiory: Drs. Lazear and Agramonte were classmates, hav-
ing graduated from the College of Physicians and Surgeons, New York
in June 1892.
I certify to the absolute truth of the above STATEMENT:

In testimony whereof, I affix my signature, in the City of
Havana, August 31, 1908.

Aristides Agramonte
M.D.
